welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt: “Have you ever visited a website that looked really plain or really stylish? What made it look that way—colors, layout, fonts, etc.?” Students will write short responses and then share with a neighbor.

aim.data: Objective: Understand what CSS is, how it styles web pages, and learn the difference between inline, internal, and external CSS. Begin using basic selectors to apply styles.

review.data: Connect to previous lesson on tables. Discuss how HTML provides structure and CSS provides style.

relevant.data: Mini-lecture with live demo in WebStorm. Cover: What is CSS? Ways to apply CSS (inline, internal, external). Introduce basic selectors like element, class, and ID.

interactive.data: Students create an HTML file and apply all three CSS methods (inline, internal, external). Use selectors to style headings, paragraphs, and the page background.

ownership.data: Students personalize their page by choosing colors and fonts. Apply both class and ID selectors. Experiment with conflicting styles.

resonate.data: Exit Ticket: “Which CSS method do you think is best for styling a large website? Why?” Students reflect in a short written response.

supplies.data: Computers with WebStorm, Google Chrome or similar browser, instructor projector, GitHub account for publishing.
